summary.abstract: This article examines the Cosmology attributed to the 7th-century Armenian scholar Anania Širakac'i, analyzing its sources, structure, and significance within both Byzantine and Armenian intellectual traditions. After contextualizing Anania's education within Byzantine mathematical schools—possibly including the Alexandrian tradition—the article surveys the state of philological research on his attributed corpus of approximately 29 works. The Cosmology's primary source is identified as St Basil's Hexameron, used in its Armenian version, while Anania also draws on pagan philosophical traditions including Aristotelian natural philosophy. The work is notable for innovating a new genre in Armenian literature—a cosmological compendium incorporating both Christian and pagan sources—comparable to Isidore of Seville's De Natura Rerum in the Latin West.
